Optimization back-end
Supports loop closure
Sparse mapping
Uses deep learning from three aspects: depth estimation, pose estimation, and uncertainty estimation
Prediction depth, pose and uncertainty are closely combined into a direct visual odometer to simultaneously improve the performance of front-end tracking and back-end nonlinear optimization
cons: Self-supervised methods are difficult to adapt to all environments

pros: Solved the limitations of the above methods (traditional methods)
Local and global features are extracted from each frame using CNN
Features are then fed into modern SLAM pipelines for posture tracking, local mapping, and repositioning
Achieves higher efficiency and lower computational cost compared with traditional BOW-based methods
Uses deep learning to find keypoints that resemble SuperPoints and to produce both the general descriptors and the images’ keypoints
Trained a cutting-edge deep CNN titled HF-NET to produce frame- and keypoint-based descriptions by extracting local and global information from each frame
Used the offline Bag of Words (BoW) method to train a visual vocabulary of local characteristics for precise loop closure recognition
Operates in real-time without using a Graphics Processing Unit (GPU) and is compatible with contemporary CPUs
Has a great ability to resist dynamic changes in dynamic contexts
Could achieve more accurate results than ORB-SLAM 2.0 and DS-SLAM
cons: Complex architecture for feature extraction
Incorporation of deep features into old SLAM framework

pros: Deep Visual SLAM for Monocular, Stereo, and RGB-D Cameras
Uses a conventional small LSTM network to process the original data of IMU and obtain the motion characteristics under IMU data
Combines visual motion features with IMU motion features, and sends it into a core LSTM network for feature fusion and pose estimation
Self-supervised Deep Learning of Monocular Visual Inertial Odometry using 3D Geometric Constraints
Semantic Visual SLAM for Dynamic Environments
Dense Semantic SLAM for Indoor Environment Using CPU Computing
Multi-modal system that couples camera, LiDAR, IMU, and UWB
Presented a map-matching marginalization scheme for visual features based on the local map constructed from LiDAR point clouds
Contains a synchronization scheme and trigger for the utilized sensors
cons: Computationally intensive due to handling synchronization, multi-threading, and sensor conflict resolution

pros: Deep feature matching-based VSLAM framework for weakly textured situations
Fed with feature masks from an enhanced LoFTR algorithm for local image feature matching
Robust feature-matching results and performance
cons: Computationally demanding

pros: Used for multi-object tracking detected by the semantic feature extractor
Real-time, edge-assisted semantic VSLAM system for mobile and resource-constrained devices
Employs a series of fine-grained modules to be used by an edge server and the associated mobile devices rather than requiring heavy threads
Semantic segmentation module based on Mask R-CNN is included to improve segmentation and object tracking
Avoided duplicate processing by reusing the findings of the object segmentation
Adapted system parameters to different network bandwidth and latency situations
Lightweight graph-based VSLAM framework for aerial robotics
Real-time system
Integrates geometrical data, several object detection techniques, and visual/visual-inertial odometry for pose estimation and building the semantic map of the environment
Leverages low-level characteristics, IMU measurements, and high-level planar information to reconstruct sparse semantic maps and predict robot states
Leverages the lightweight version of You Only Look Once v2.0 (YOLO2) trained on the COCO dataset for object detection due to its real-time and computationally effective performance
Could provide results that were on par with those of well-known VSLAM methods
cons: Only a small number of objects (e.g., chairs, books, and laptops) can be used by their VSLAM system to build a semantic map of the surrounding area

pros: Suggested using edge computing to enable the offloading of resource-intensive operations to the cloud and reduce the computational burden on the robot
Modified the architecture of ORB-SLAM 2.0 by maintaining the tracking module on the robot and delegating the remainder to the edge
Can maintain both a local and a global map
Could still execute properly without sacrificing accuracy with fewer resources available
cons: Architecture’s complexity due to the decoupling of various SLAM modules

pros: Works with monocular and stereo-vision cameras
Lessens the computational load by limiting the extraction of features to keyframes and monitoring them in subsequent frames by eliminating photo-metric errors
Hybrid strategy that combines the virtues of the direct and indirect categories of VSLAM algorithms
Surpasses several popular techniques in terms of performance and accuracy
Active technique for omnidirectional robots with RGB-D cameras
Includes a module for spotting obstructions in the camera’s area of vision
Primary objective is to lessen the distance the robot must go to map the environment by offering observation coverage of previously unexplored places and previously visited locations
Uses a VSLAM framework with graph features as its back-end
Could attain outcomes that were on par with those of cutting-edge VSLAM methods
cons: Robot might face start-stop cases in which the local paths are re-planned

pros: Text-based VSLAM system that incorporates text items retrieved from the scene using the FAST corner detection technique in the SLAM pipeline
Uses texts as reliable visual fiducial markers
Parametrizes texts after the first frame in which they are found
Projects the 3D text object onto the target image to locate it again
Presented a new three-variable parameterization technique for initializing instantaneous text features
cons: Cannot operate in text-free surroundings
Difficulty interpreting short letters
Requires the storage of enormous text dictionaries
